description: From Middle English mery, merie, mirie, myrie, murie, murȝe, from Old English meriġe, miriġe, myriġe, myreġe, myrġe (“pleasing, agreeable; pleasant, sweet, delightful; melodious”), from Proto-Germanic *murguz (“short, slow”), from Proto-Indo-European *mréǵʰus (“short”). Cognate with Scots mery, mirry (“merry”), Middle Dutch mergelijc (“pleasant, agreeable, joyful”), Norwegian dialectal myrjel (“small object, figurine”), Latin brevis (“short, small, narrow, shallow”), Ancient Greek βραχύς (brakhús, “short”). Doublet of brief.

entries.meaning: Jolly and full of high spirits; happy.
examples: We had a very merry Christmas.

entries.meaning: Festive and full of fun and laughter.
examples: Everyone was merry at the party.
The play moved along at a merry pace.
The car moved at a merry clip.

entries.meaning: Causing laughter, mirth, gladness, or delight.

examples: Some of us got a little merry at the office Christmas party.
